title: 108_hr3106
content: The Act titled "Removal of Terrorist Criminal Aliens Act of 2003" allows for expedited removal of terrorist criminal aliens under section 238A of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the discretion to determine deportability and issue a final removal order for aliens convicted of specific criminal offenses or engaged in activities endangering national security. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the discretion to execute removal orders for aliens, with exceptions for judicial review and stays of removal. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the discretion to execute removal orders for aliens, with exceptions for judicial review and stays of removal. Courts have jurisdiction to review orders related to aliens convicted of specific offenses, with proceedings following regulations set by the Secretary. The alien in removal proceedings has the right to choose counsel, inspect evidence, have a determination made on record, maintain a record for judicial review, and not have the final order adjudicated by the same person who issues the charges. No alien in removal proceedings shall be eligible for certain relief under the immigration laws of the United States. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL REMOVAL AUTHORITIES. "238A. Expedited removal of terrorist criminal aliens." Section 241(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security" and allow for alternative countries for alien removal if designated countries are not feasible. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the discretion to remove an alien to their country of citizenship or any country willing to accept them if the designated country is not feasible for removal. The Secretary of Homeland Security can remove an alien to their country of citizenship or any country willing to accept them if the designated country is not feasible for removal. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to any deportation, exclusion, or removal order regardless of its finality. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF ALIENS POSING A DANGER TO NATIONAL SECURITY. Section 237(a)(4) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for the deportation of aliens posing a national security threat, excluding lawful permanent residents. The Attorney General and Secretary of Homeland Security are delegated authority to make such determinations. The authority to determine deportability for national security threats is limited to the Deputy Attorney General and Deputy Secretary of Homeland Security. They can consider the best available information from the intelligence community. The authority to determine deportability for national security threats is limited to the Deputy Attorney General and Deputy Secretary of Homeland Security. They consult with appropriate heads of agencies and any challenge to their determination must provide a legitimate reason. An alien deportable under this rule is not eligible for relief from removal or withholding of removal. No court has jurisdiction to review a denial of relief or withholding made for national security threats.
